Graph Structure Code Implementation
up">labuladongOriginalAbout 6406 words

up">labuladong labuladong labuladong Original About 6406 words About 6406 words

Prerequisites

Before reading this article, you should first study:

  • Recursion/Level Order Traversal of N-ary Trees

In a Nutshell

A graph is an extension of the N-ary tree structure. Logically, a graph consists of multiple nodes (Vertices) and edges. We usually use adjacency lists or adjacency matrices to store graphs.

In a tree, only parent nodes can point to child nodes; there are no child-to-parent links, and child nodes do not link to each other. In contrast, graphs do not have these restrictions窶馬odes can point to each other, forming complex networks.

The visual panel supports creating graph structures. You can open the panel below to see the logical structure of a graph, and how adjacency lists and matrices are used to store it:

Algorithm visualize
ﾂ Algorithm VisualizationLink copied!

Graphs can abstract many complex problems and have led to many classic graph algorithms, such as Bipartite Graph Algorithm, Topological Sort, Shortest Path Algorithm, and Minimum Spanning Tree Algorithm. These topics will be introduced later.

This article mainly introduces the basic concepts of graphs and how to implement graph structures in code.

Logical Structure of Graph

Adjacency List and Adjacency Matrix
